title: Linux Process Debugging
question: A process is consuming 100% CPU on a Linux server. Walk me through how you would identify and troubleshoot this issue.
answer: Start with top or htop to identify the process. Use ps aux to get details. Check strace to see system calls, lsof for open files, and /proc/<pid>/ for process info. For Java/Python, get thread dumps. Check logs, and consider perf or flamegraphs for deep analysis. May indicate infinite loops, memory leaks, or resource contention.
explanation: Systematic troubleshooting is essential for production issues. Starting with broad tools (top) and narrowing down (strace, perf) helps identify root causes efficiently. Understanding Linux process management and debugging tools is a core DevOps skill.

codeExamples.label: Identify high CPU process
codeExamples.code:
# Find top CPU consumers
top -bn1 | head -20

# Sort by CPU usage
ps aux --sort=-%cpu | head -10

# Get process details
ps -p <PID> -o pid,ppid,cmd,%cpu,%mem,etime

# Check process tree
pstree -p <PID>

codeExamples.label: Deep process analysis
codeExamples.code:
# Trace system calls
strace -p <PID> -c  # Summary
strace -p <PID> -f  # Follow forks

# Check open files and connections
lsof -p <PID>

# View process memory map
cat /proc/<PID>/maps

# CPU profiling with perf
perf record -p <PID> -g -- sleep 30
perf report

commonMistakes: Immediately killing the process without investigating the root cause
Not checking if the high CPU is expected (batch job, build process)
Forgetting to check system logs before diving into process-level debugging
